p: In one of the latest editions of European Pharmacopoeia [ 52] and the French Pharmacopoeia [ 53], A. vulgaris is listed as a homeopathic raw material. Its application includes the treatment of irregular menstrual cycles and menopausal symptoms [ 7], and nervous disorders such as sleepwalking, seizures, epilepsy, and anxiety [ 99]. The homeopathic medications are prepared using a fresh-root tincture, which is made of 65% ethanol. The tincture should contain a minimum of 0.01% ( w/ w) derivatives of hydroxycinnamic acid, quantified as the equivalents of chlorogenic acid [ 100].
